Name: PIRIMIPHOS-METHYL
Description: Pirimiphos-methyl is an organic thiophosphate that is O,O-dimethyl O-pyrimidin-4-yl phosphorothioate substituted by a methyl group at position 6 and a diethylamino group at position 2. It has a role as an EC 3.1.1.7 (acetylcholinesterase) inhibitor, an acaricide, an agrochemical, an insecticide and an environmental contaminant. It is an organic thiophosphate and an aminopyrimidine. It is functionally related to a 2-diethylamino-6-methylpyrimidin-4(1H)-one.

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Ghini S et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 47: 479-88 (2004)
animal_concentrations.Value: Pirimiphos-methyl was detected in 44% of honeybee samples at concentrations of 0.001 to 0.062 mg/kg, dead bee samples were collected in bags suspended under beehives (only worker bees were analyzed) in the district of Bologna, Italy(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Mansour SA; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 196: 1-51 (2008)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Pirimiphos-methyl was detected in fish samples (types, locations and dates of fish samples not reported) from locations in Egypt at 50.5 ppb(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Mansour SA; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 196: 1-51 (2008)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Pirimiphos-methyl was not detected in sediment samples (locations and dates of samples not reported) from locations in Egypt(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Amelung W et al; J AOAC Int 90: 1659-69 (2007)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: In the Bangkok area of Thailand, pirimiphos-methyl was not detected in the soil of soybean, onion, Chinese kale fields or citrus plantations(1).

plant_translocation.References: Antonious, G. F., & Snyder, J. C. (1995). Pirimiphos-methyl residues and control of greenhouse whitefly (Homoptera: Aleyrodidae) on seven vegetables. Journal of Entomological Science, 30(2), 191-201
plant_translocation.Value: Pirimiphos-methyl, commercially known as Actellic®, is an organophosphorus insecticide employed in agricultural practices to combat various insect pests affecting crops. Pirimiphos-methyl does not possess systemic properties. This signifies that its mode of action is primarily confined to the application sites, such as the surfaces of leaves and fruits. This attribute is underscored by its swift dissipation from the treated plant surfaces, a phenomenon corroborated by the study's results. The absence of significant systemic movement implies that pirimiphos-methyl's efficacy and impact are predominantly localized, exerting control over pests directly exposed to the treated areas. Pirimiphos-methyl's influence is largely restricted to its point of application, rather than being extensively transported throughout the plant's vascular system.
